item.title: Math and Worldbuilding
item.description:
The Neglect of Mathematics and Game Balance in Tabletop Roleplaying Games

In all forms of interactive storytelling where numbers are involved, the narratives and imaginations of those involved are grounded in and informed by the underlying mathematics and mechanics. Just like in the real world, math is the basis on which everything exists - change one variable, and the world and the cultures within will look much different. Despite this foundational importance, the math in TTRPGs is often neglected or not taken into consideration during its creation, causing the stories built on it to lack plausibility or the players to engage in degenerate gameplay loops that are better incentivized by the math. We must elevate the standards of game balance and mathematical principles within to ensure a stable play environment with maximal freedom of storytelling.
For the purpose of this discussion, I'll mostly be referring to the design of Dungeons and Dragons, but these principles extend to all games, TTRPG or otherwise.


Here in the real world, our actions are most often decided by their expected outcomes. People grow the food that produces the most in the local terrain, they wear protection to avoid death, they take the path of least resistance, they outlaw actions that harm others. If the outcomes or goals were different, the actions taken would be different - if stabbing someone was a pleasant experience that extended their lifespan, then the laws around stabbing people would be very different. If we only ate for pleasure, we would grow what tasted the best regardless of climate. 
This is true down to the very foundations of the universe, where the actions that the atoms and forces of the universe take are decided by simple rules. Light takes the path of least time, mass and energy act towards increased entropy, and other such rules determine how everything else acts.
Just like in real life, expected outcomes are what guide us in TTRPGs. If the goal of the player is to live the longest and kill the most things, then the actions they take will be guided by what best gets them to that goal. Because this is based on probability, it becomes a question of simple math to determine the best course of action at a given moment. All else the same, the weapon that does the most damage should be what everybody in the world defaults to. All else the same, the strategy that prevents the most damage taken is the best. 
Math IS worldbuilding. 

In real life, we can't fight against monsters and men-at-arms with shuriken and our bare fists. Reality dictates that those actions would likely result in our demise. However, in a game, we often find ourselves roleplaying something that isn't exactly realistic - such as a magician slinging fireballs at ogres. If we want to allow the full range of themes to be represented in a game, we need all of them to be on a fair playing field. There is no purpose to allowing "Unarmed Strike" as an action that accomplishes nothing and gets you killed, after all - but we decide the rules of this universe. We can make "Unarmed Strike" deal substantial damage, or have additional benefits that make their use reasonable. By setting the rules properly, what is feasible changes to match our desires.
Whether what you desire is a good thing is a discussion for another day - let's focus on the hows.
What players do is a combination of what they desire, and what the game rewards. Developers should set the rules to reward what they want to happen, and not reward what they don't. Ideally, the incentives should match what the players want to do.

The incentive structure of a game like DnD usually comes in the form of power. More money and experience means bigger and more magical swords and fireballs, or more hirelings, etcetera. When you want a fair game for players to enjoy various themes and strategies, you must balance the power such that there is not a single overwhelmingly dominant strategy that is easily recognized by players. This is only fair; if you have multiple players, and one is given obviously inferior power, they may experience frustration or disengagement when they notice their impact on the game is insubstantial as a result.
Fairness in a system of mathematics is fundamentally a question of mathematics.
When the underlying math is neglected, and the rest of the game is built despite it, you will quickly find oddities. If you make "Unarmed Strike" deal 1 damage, and "Longsword" deal between 1 and 8, you should not be surprised when nobody will opt for "Unarmed Strike" under any circumstances. If there is a dominant strategy, and yet you still declare that most of the people in this world fight with fists instead of swords (all else equal), your world becomes less believable. From the math, the rest of the world-building should come naturally and without significant leaps of logic - If you declare something exists in this world, there should be a basis for it, and this basis almost always comes from the math.
Balanced systems inherently foster deeper engagement. Players are more likely to invest their time into the mechanics of a game when they believe they will not be held back by deviating from superior strategies. By employing mathematical approaches to skill scaling, damage output, resource allocation, and character progression, players are free to choose options based on thematics, creativity, and their own desires without worrying about doing the math on behalf of the developers to make sure they are being dealt a fair hand.
Everything I've stated so far may seem obvious, and even patronizing, but the reality is that most developers do not take this into consideration as much as they should.

I'll spare you the fine details and skip to the important math to keep in mind. 
In DnD, there are listed weapons that are assumed to be available from character creation. If we consider the world in which this takes place, it would be fair to assume that the people in the world would also want to survive encounters when selecting their weaponry, and those weapons are boiled down to sets of numbers and tags to describe them. The most important number to a commoner with no bonuses to anything is the damage number - in a fight, the odds to succeed are highest by simply using the weapon with the highest damage. And yet, a dagger deals 2.5 damage, while a stick deals 3.5. If they use a very big stick, they can even reach 4.5, if they don't mind using both hands. If they spend some more money and actions, they can use two axes for a whopping 7 damage, and this is only with "simple" weapons they may be proficient in.
The simple conclusion here is that, all else equal, a commoner's preferred weapon should be a stick, or two axes if they have money to spare. The stick is the most versatile, cheap, and powerful weapon available to them. Even if you take into account the bonuses from stats, a commoner would need maximum dexterity to consider a dagger, even compared to weapons they are not proficient in. In this world, using a dagger is mathematically inferior to every other option for any regular, non-player character. 
This results in a silly world that only suits the players, without taking into account the rest of the creatures. Why would a knife be a substantially worse weapon than a stick? 
A goat that attacks a human is likely to kill them in a single attack. How long would a farmer last in such a world?
Some classes and builds can easily survive far longer and deal multiple times as much damage as others, often while being better at non-combat activities as well. Why would anyone willingly choose to be the inferior class if the objective is to survive? 
The expected earnings of a player far outpace the earnings of commoners, as untrained labor is only enough to pay for a gallon of ale or a stay at a poor inn while a single piece of basic equipment can be worth a hundred times as much. Is it really acceptable to put the price on a day of deadly work (such as a mercenary) equal to the price of a dagger, one of the worst items in the game, such that a player could hire dozens of them for every adventure?
How long can you ride on a player's goodwill and desire for thematics and roleplay before these poor worldbuilding decisions start to interfere with their fantasy?

One of the most insidious phenomena in the world of TTRPGs is the tendency of players to defend poor mathematics and imbalanced mechanics, often born out of a fundamental misunderstanding or intentional ignorance of underlying principles. This defense frequently stems from a place of trust in the developers and an emotional attachment to the game itself, leading players to uphold the perceived authority of the creators.

"If they wanted it that way, they would have made it that way!"
"You think they didn't think of that? They clearly left it like that for a reason."
"Why don't you do better, then?"
When players encounter a system that is hailed as "official," there is a natural inclination to assume that the developers have meticulously crafted every detail, and thus, their choices are unquestionable. Players may erroneously believe that since the developers designed the game, they must have considered every possible variable and outcome, rendering any criticism unwarranted. 
Players may also propagate the myth of developer infallibility, asserting that they are privy to unique insights that justify design decisions. Such attitudes not only inhibit constructive discourse, but they also diminish the validity of collective player experiences and insights, as an entire community’s lived experiences may be rendered irrelevant in the face of perceived expertise. The belief that there "can’t be a better way" is a common claim that started among video game developers, such as at Riot Games and Nexon, as they frequently cite data they claim exists to justify their actions while refusing to release said data to prove it. The truth is that no such data exists, and modern gaming communities can easily get access to or create superior data from which to make decisions.
When confronted with suggestions for rebalance, players often leap to the defense of their cherished mechanics, positing that the developers "must have had a reason" for their choices. This blind and aggressive defense of the systems further perpetuates the cycle of flawed designs, as those advocating for improvement or merely offering their observations are dismissed as "Powergamers," or told that they're just not focusing on what matters, and that roleplay trumps game design.
Because the foundation of these defenses is inherently fallacious, they almost always lead to a statement that reveals their lack of engagement with the topic. The most common ones include that the game is made to be changed from table to table, that the suggestions are merely opinions and do not represent the needs of the community, that the opinions of those that are not part of successful gaming companies are inherently worthless, and basic attacks on the character of those criticizing the game (rather than focusing on the criticisms themselves).

Most players lack the mathematical literacy necessary to fully grasp the implications of game mechanics at a detailed level. Consequently, when flaws in balance emerge—be they overpowered abilities, inefficient resource distribution, or underwhelming options—players may misinterpret these issues as subjective preferences rather than objective mathematical failings. 
The most common misinterpretation of the math is that of percentage reductions: Most players do not know that reducing an effect by 100% is far more than twice as good as reducing it by 50%. A common way this ignorance appears is in video games such as League of Legends, Minecraft, and Skyrim, where players will honestly believe that combining a reduction of 50% with another 50% and getting a result of 75% is somehow a "diminished" effect because the total did not reach 100%, when in reality the result is a multiplicative, mathematically accurate, and fair way to represent the effect.
Combined with the aforementioned bias towards that which is "official," a majority of the population will convince themselves that their intuitive (incorrect) understanding of the underlying mathematics is also aligned with what the developers think - and, unfortunately, they may be correct.

The methods used by the developers of DnD to create the game and the underlying math is transparently dubious. By their own (unwitting) admission, the top-down approaches used by them with a lack of emphasis on mechanics and math, insufficient player testing, and dismissal of community feedback has led to books full of wondrous descriptions of a game that does not accurately match their vision in practice.
The examples of such are too numerous to list, but to bring up simultaneous examples that perfectly encapsulate the sheer nescience of the lead developers of DnD, we can look at the playtests of DnD 5.5. During the playtests, the developers made a particularly bizarre public video about the results, falsely claiming that a mechanic that players did not interact with was "mathematically one of the most powerful" when it was the worst on average, dismissing feedback because player scores on individual features were higher than the overall score, and even incorrectly referencing their own changes to their own content. 
What truly happened behind the scenes to cause such a public statement to be made without any proofreading is unclear. It's up to a given individual to review these actions to decide whether it's negligence, ignorance, or deliberate equivocation. I try taking the most charitable approach by assigning ignorance to what could have just as easily been malice.

Game developers must adopt a mathematical mindset in their approach. This includes rigorous playtesting with statistical analyses, iterative balancing, and a commitment to utilizing clear metrics for evaluating the effectiveness and fairness of mechanics while maintaining consistency and logic. Checking published content for faults should not be the burden of the players, especially when the product is advertised as being beginner-friendly. Disparities that can be encountered within a new player's first turn should not be tolerated, let alone upheld as intended design.
Players should be involved in the balancing process, and even perceived faults in criticism should be thoroughly investigated to identify the underlying reasons for the criticisms being put forth. When a community is particularly large, there's a high likelihood that there will be individuals that practically design the game in its entirety in their criticisms. To dismiss them is the peak of hubris. 
When a game's fundamentals and mathematical foundations are made airtight, the content built on them will likewise be untouchable. Under ideal circumstances, even inexperienced players should be able to expand on the content in the game with little worry of diminishing the balance. I hope to one day live in a world where criticisms of game balance and mathematics are truly in the realm of the nitpicking and biased, and that all game discussion becomes that of themes and abstractions.

item.title: Encode or Decode Documents
item.description: Using Linguistics, you can write things in ways that are difficult to interpret without a cipher, such as disguising your forbidden ritual as a cookbook. The DC to your code is 10+(Linguistics bonus). Creatures that know the code can read encoded text, but creatures that don't will interpret the text as something else. To read encoded text, you must first crack the code, usually requiring at least a week of research. At the end of the week, roll a Linguistics check versus the writer’s DC to crack the code.
item.guid: Skills/Linguistics/Encode or Decode Documents.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Interpret Text
item.description: Using Linguistics, you peruse a book, contract, or other written work to quickly summarize what it says in one minute. The DC for most works is 10, but it changes based on the size and complexity of the work at hand. Failure indicates more time is necessary to understand what the text contains. Finding oddities in a contract requires an opposed Linguistics check.
item.guid: Skills/Linguistics/Interpret Text.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Linguistics
item.description:
INT-based Skill.
Proficiency in Linguistics grants an additional known Language per level.
Used for Interpret Text, Write or Forge Documents, and Encode or Decode Documents.
item.guid: Skills/Linguistics/Linguistics.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Write or Forge Documents
item.description: Using Linguistics, you can make contracts, forge signatures, and make fake (or real) documents look official. Noticing oddities in such documents requires an opposed Linguistics check.
item.guid: Skills/Linguistics/Write or Forge Documents.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Take 30
item.description: When not under duress, you can spend ten times the time the task normally takes to achieve your best effort, automatically getting a Natural 30. It is assumed you trigger the failure result ten times, making this unsuitable for crafting or disarming traps.
item.guid: Skills/Take 30.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Forge Documents
item.description: Using Linguistics, you can make contracts, forge signatures, and make fake (or real) documents look official. Noticing oddities in such documents requires an opposed Linguistics check.
item.guid: Write/Forge Documents.md

item.title: Speed
item.description:
Default ground movement speed is 30.
Race, Class, Equipment, and Status can change this.
Some actions grant extra speed.
You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Speed.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Jump
item.description:
Jump in a straight line. This can only be used in combination with other forms of movement such as walking or charging.
Jump is also a statistic. By default, your Jump is 5. This is a measure of distance, specifically for horizontal jumps, while vertical jumps are half. This does not give you additional movement, and the thus it is limited by your speed. It can be used to avoid difficult terrain, but not if you're already in the difficult terrain.
You can only jump once with this action. If you Dash, you can jump twice. These jumps do not need to be consecutive.
Jump distance increases by 5 ft per point of DEX (and STR with Athletics).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Jump.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: AS
item.description:
Attack Speed (AS): In order to decide how many attacks to make, you must use the AS of anything available to you when you take your Attack Action. Most weapons have an AS greater than 1, allowing you to make multiple attacks. If you have multiple ways to attack, you can combine them together. However, you cannot "overlap" your AS. To visualize this -

Here we have a character that has a dagger in hand with an AS of 5, a mace in the other with an AS of 3, and multiple Action-Attacks with an AS of 1. He can take one action from every column, meaning if you use a Spell (AS-1) you can no longer do any attacks that use the same column. He could do

5 dagger attacks
4 dagger attacks and a Spell
a Special Attack and 2 mace attacks and 2 dagger attacks, etc...
However, he cannot do a Spell and a Special Attack on the same turn, as they only have an AS of 1 individually.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/AS.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Attack
item.description:
Attack rolls are any type of harmful effect targeting a creature that does not require a saving throw. This can be spells, swords, or trying to push your foe off of a cliff (see Combat Maneuvers).
Default: Roll+ACC+/-(circumstantial bonuses or penalties)
When you roll an attack, you compare it to the target's AC. If you roll under it, you miss, and you usually deal no damage. If you meet it, you hit, and roll the damage associated with the attack. If you roll 20 or more points over their Avoid, you Critically Strike (Crit), adding your Critical Damage to the attack.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Attack.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Crit
item.description:
Critical Hit: an Attack that adds Critical Damage.
Normally, this is a result of rolling an attack and beating their AC by 20 or more.
Other abilities may change the conditions needed to score a Critical Hit.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Crit.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Dual Wielding
item.description: When using something in each hand, you gain the full benefits of both. You may benefit from two staves granting casting bonuses, use both of their AS, a sword and shield - whatever you like. If you use two weapons of the same AS, they gain +1 AS. Both weapons must be used at least once. You cannot engage in Dual-Wielding if you have a Two-Handed item. For example, you cannot swing a greatsword and then use Unarmed Strikes or throw shuriken with their higher AS.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Dual Wielding.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Ranged Attack
item.description:
A Ranged Attack is an Attack made with ranged targeting. This means you can make the attack up to the listed range, not limited by the space you Threaten. These attacks can also be penalized due to Cover. Physical Ranged Attacks have two listed ranges - the first is Close Range and the second is Long Range.
Making a Ranged Attack Provokes.
Abilities that function from a distance but do not use an Attack Roll are not Ranged Attacks.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Ranged Attack.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: HP
item.description:
Hitpoints (HP) are a representation of how much offense you can weather. If you run out of HP, you are Defeated. Your total HP is determined primarily by Class, but can also be augmented by abilities, Feats, and even Race.
When you take Damage, you reduce your current HP out of your normal maximum HP. Your HP value can be negative.
Every character with a class starts with 30 HP, with an additional bonus from their class every level (Usually around +10).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/HP.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Alchemy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Oozes.
Used for Identify Potion, Identify Composition, and Craft alchemical items.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Alchemy/Alchemy.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Arcana
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Monsters.
Used for Identify Spell and Identify Magic Item.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Arcana/Arcana.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Identify Spell
item.description:
By observing a Spell as it is being cast, you can Instantly use Arcana to identify which Spell it is. The DC is 5 per level of the Technique (not including Upcast.)
This is useful for determining whether you want to take action in response, or it has no immediate effect - though many Spells do not need to be identified if you already know the spell.
You may use Astronomy to identify Lunar spells, and Nature to identify Gaia spells.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Arcana/Identify Spell.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Astronomy
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Abominations.
Used for Navigation, Identify Spell, and Identify Cosmic Phenomenon.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Astronomy/Astronomy.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Identify Cosmic Phenomenon
item.description:
Using Astronomy with aid of devices such as telescopes (if necessary), you can determine the cause of cosmic phenomenon, or you can predict them in advance. This can be something like a solar eclipse, a comet, or something more drastic like a meteor or supernova.
You can also tell if something unusual is happening, such as someone using illusions to improperly represent the night sky, or cast spells that produce effects similar to cosmic phenomenon.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Astronomy/Identify Cosmic Phenomenon.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Navigation
item.description: With a clear view of the night time sky, you can determine where you are and where you need to be. You can use Astronomy as an alternative to Survival for navigation in such circumstances. This skill replaces Survival during space travel.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Astronomy/Navigation.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Civilization
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Humanoids and Titans.
Used for Recall Customs, Recognize Figure, and Recall Locale.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Civilization/Civilization.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Recall Customs
item.description: Using Civilization, you can recall information about how to conduct yourself with foreign cultures. This can be particularly useful when trying to gain someone's favor, such as royalty. You can also recall information about holidays, festivals and ceremonies.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Civilization/Recall Customs.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Recall Locale
item.description: Using Civilization, you can recall the answer to a specific simple question such as "where can I buy potions?" or "where does the royalty live?" or "where can I hire someone to build something?" These questions can be applied to the town you're in or with a higher DC, something much bigger like a country or continent.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Civilization/Recall Locale.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Recognize Figure
item.description: Using Civilization, you can attach a name to a face, or vice versa. You generally understand aspects of a creature's reputation, their affiliations, and their general capabilities. Exceptionally high rolls might even land you some secrets or gossip related to this creature.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Civilization/Recognize Figure.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Engineering
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Constructs.
Used for Identify Function, Hack, and Identify Structural Quirk.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Engineering/Engineering.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Hack
item.description: Using Engineering, where there exists technology, there exists a method to disable or gain control of it, even if only temporarily. Hacking always requires a hands-on approach.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Engineering/Hack.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Identify Function
item.description: Use Engineering to identify the purpose of particularly complex machinery. Depending on the size and scope of what you're looking at, this could only be a glance, or it could require a few minutes, and usually requires a hands-on approach.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Engineering/Identify Function.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Identify Structural Quirk
item.description: Large scale buildings such as castles, watchtowers, walls, factories, prisons etc. Are all built with specific purposes, facilities and defenses in mind. You can use Engineering to figure out aspects of these buildings, such as where exhaust/waste pipes lead, how far underground you might need to go to go underneath the structure, and even structural weaknesses.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Engineering/Identify Structural Quirk.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Identify Natural Phenomenon
item.description:
Use Nature to identify natural processes like photosynthesis, the reproduction of creatures, and tectonic activity. You can do things like figuring out if a volcano is about to erupt, what could be causing plants to die, or how long until an egg hatches.
You can also identify natural fauna, flora, and minerals, and their potential uses.
When used to predict weather, you need to roll well to accurately predict more than a day ahead. You can also tell whether the weather is natural, or if it's being caused by magic.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Nature/Identify Natural Phenomenon.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Nature
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Plants, Fey, and Beasts.
Used for Identify Natural Phenomenon and Identify Spell.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Nature/Nature.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Detect Portal
item.description:
Using Planes, you can detect, identify, and disable portals.
Portals are strange phenomenon, but there are signs that they exist miles away from where the portal is actually located. If a portal is naturally occurring, you can use a DC 30 check to find its general area, or where it appears if it is not currently open. If it's manufactured, you can use a DC 20 check, or the caster's opposed Arcana, whichever is higher.
In the presence of a portal, you can tell where its destination plane is. Rolling higher can give more specific locations, more details about the portals creation and how often it gets used. This starts at DC 10.
Disabling a portal is a task that is very difficult by one's self. Failure could mean getting stuck on the wrong side of the portal, or hyper-charging the portal to attract extraplanar creatures. Using Planes is usually a short-term and rushed method. The DC starts at 30.
Using a Ritual with Invocation and Arcana can make the process of disabling a portal more safe.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Planes/Detect Portal.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Planes
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Fiends, Celestials, and Elementals.
Used for Detect Portal.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Planes/Planes.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Divine Lore
item.description: Using Religion, you can identify a symbol (DC 10) tied to a person, object, or locale to determine its religious affiliation, as well as the tenets (DC 15) of a given religion and its chosen (DC 20) artifacts, people, and events of significance. You can also determine how to gain favor from a particular god (DC 15).
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Religion/Divine Lore.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Religion
item.description:
INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill.
Allows the use of Monster Lore on Undead.
Used for Divine Lore.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Religion/Religion.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: History
item.description:
All Knowledge Skills can be used to glean relevant History for their subject matters.
The includes recalling major events, figures, artifacts, and deciphering hieroglyphs.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/History.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Knowledge
item.description:
INT-based Skill. You cannot roll Knowledge if you are not Trained.
Knowledge is broken up into many different skills based on subject, and each one has a subsection dedicated to Monster Lore of specific types of creatures. Monster Lore isn’t its own skill, it is instead an action that uses the individual Knowledge skills. If a subject or creature falls into multiple categories, then players can choose whichever they like more, but an individual character can't roll multiple checks with different skills - instead, they receive a +2 bonus for each overlapping Knowledge they possess.
If you want to know who an individual creature is and their relevance to the world, rather than their stats and abilities, the DC is usually dependent on how popular they are. This is typically 30-LV with additional reductions to the DC if they are famous or in a position of power, or increases in the DC if they work to keep their identity and exploits hidden.
All Knowledge Skills can be used to recall the History of the associated subject as well, such as using Civilization to learn about ancient Elf-Human relations that shaped the current world.
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Knowledge.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Monster Lore
item.description:
Adventurers are assumed to know basic things about monsters, like how a Construct's lack of anatomy grants them resistance to many effects, or the properties of Incorporeal creatures. Monster Lore checks are for figuring out more information about specific monster types, or if a creature is hiding its typing.
Monster stat blocks are broken up into sections. Basic stats (Saves, HP and AC), offense traits (breath weapons, dangerous auras, prominent spells), defense traits (healing abilities, elemental Resistances), other traits (extra senses, extra movement options, out of combat abilities) and weaknesses/deep lore (lich's phylactery, vampires not appearing in mirrors).
Rolling a Monster Lore check is something you can do as a Free Action once per turn. It is assumed that you also vocalize what you learn to your team. The base DC of a Monster Lore check is (10+creature's LV). By succeeding on a Monster Lore check, you can figure out a creature's basic stats and one other category for your choice. For every 5 over the DC you roll, you figure out another category. If a creature has nothing in a category, you choose another.
Creatures with the [unique] tag in their entry increase their Monster Lore DC by 5. Humanoids with class levels by default are assumed to have the [unique] tag, unless their class comes with clearly distinguishable features (such as a Dark Knight's Evil Eye), or they are part of an organization with similar training and abilities (such as a Monk dojo or city guards).
item.guid: Skills/Knowledge/Monster Lore.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Achievement
item.description: Achievements are archetypal tasks that provide some kind of tangible benefit after completion. You do not need to opt into an achievement, instead they can be claimed retroactively after accomplishing a task.
item.guid: Classes/Class/Achievements/Achievement.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Backstabber
item.description:
Achievement
Requirement - Murder 3 people you once considered allies, or who at thought you were an ally (before you turned on them). If you murder someone in a position of great power, like a powerful guild leader or king, it counts as 3.
Reward - You have a 6th sense for when people trust you. By observing how they react to your presence in a brief interaction (such as an introduction), you can tell whether they trust you, are indifferent towards you or if they distrust you.
item.guid: Classes/Class/Achievements/Backstabber.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Battle Scars
item.description:
Achievement
Requirement - Get defeated by a critical hit and survive in 3 different encounters. Or get crit 3 times in the same combat and survive.
Reward - The scars you get from battle are deeply entrenched in your memory. Your memories of combats you have encountered cannot be magically removed. By touching them, you can perfectly recall past events, as long as they happened in the thick of combat. Other creatures can touch your scars to share in the experience of the memory
item.guid: Classes/Class/Achievements/Battle Scars.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Critical Pet
item.description:
Achievement
Requirement - Use stealth to initiate combat on a creature by patting its head 3 times. This pat can have no mechanical effect such as delivering a spell or attacking.
Reward - You unlock the "Pet" skill. It uses your stealth bonus. If you sneak up on a creature and pet their head (again, no additional mechanical effect), you establish dominance, giving you a +2 bonus to skills for the subsequent social or combat encounter. If a creature within reach is smaller than you, you can pet them as a free action 1/turn for no mechanical benefit (no save).
item.guid: Classes/Class/Achievements/Critical Pet.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Character Creation
item.description:
There are several things for you to decide when deciding what you're writing down on your character sheet. Start with a theme, aesthetic, fighting style, or a particular character type you want to mimic from popular media.
These are in order of necessity for actually playing the game, but not necessarily in the order that is most convenient to any individual's workflow.
item.guid: Classes/Class/Character Creation.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Class
item.description:
Classes are the fundamental basis from which you obtain abilities.
Classes get a set of numerical bonuses to aid them. Every class has listed HP, Skills, Mana, and at least one Save bonus. Stats can be flat front-loaded amounts, per-LV bonuses, or both.
Most characters will get their core abilities front-loaded at level 1. All classes get access to some type of Techniques, which can be martial techniques or spells. Technique points granted through class usually have some form of restriction.
Even levels are mostly dedicated to class features that directly increase the classes power. This includes gaining access to new combat abilities, increasing the power of old ones, and getting their own special attacks.
Odd levels are mostly dedicated to getting the next tier of techniques. As such, class features are usually sparse. If any are included, they are usually minor increases in power or they are flavorful inclusions. You also get a Feat every odd level.
item.guid: Classes/Class/Class.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Progression Outside of Class
item.description:
Boons/Banes - Gained at level one as a result of having positive or negative luck.
Feats - Gained at level 1, and every odd level after.
Technique Points - Gain one that can be used on any school of techniques at level 2, and every even level after.
Achievement - Can be gained at any time, even retroactively, when certain conditions are met, varying based on the achievement.
item.guid: Classes/Class/Progression Outside of Class.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Rogue
item.description:
Masters of stealth, infiltration, and execution. The rogue is "that guy" someone knows who's the man for the job. The rogue is the guy who knows people higher up in town as much as those in the underbelly of society. Out-skill and outsmart your foes with the power of planning, tactics, and playing dirty.

1 - Techniques
You gain full progression in Scoundrel and Warfare.
1 - Ability
1 - Passive
1 - Sneak Attack
Surprise attacks have +20 crit chance. In most cases, this means all Surprise attack hits are Critical Hits - you have a 100% critical hit rate with them.
1 - Critical Edge
Add another d10+LUK to your Critical Damage.
1 - Backstep
Once on your turn, during or after movement, you can move backwards on the path you took Elusive 10 ft without spending movement.
1 - Cunning Action
Once per round, gain an additional standard or swift action that can't be used to attack or cast spells. Must be a different action than you use with your standard or swift action.
1 - Dark Sight
Immediate. Gain the ability to stealth anywhere and stealth on the same action, as well as cause all accuracy checks against you to fail. Lasts five turns, or until you attack, cast a spell, or otherwise take an offensive action. Creatures that are not passively perceiving, or are otherwise occupied, do not get a check to spot you.
1 - Haste
Standard Action. Grant a touched ally +10 speed and jump for 10 minutes. Up to 3+CHA allies can benefit at the same time.
You gain this benefit passively.
2 - Evasion
You take half damage from Reflex save effects, and no damage when you pass the save.
2 - Rogue Talent
You gain a Rogue talent every even level.
4 - Stroke of Luck
(1+Luck) times per day, you can force a specific serendipitous event as a free action. Advantageous scenarios could be something like a cart of hay to catch your fall, or a bird smashing into a window to get a guard to investigate. Things with a DC of 15 or lower happens automatically. Anything higher requires a roll.
6 - Uncanny Dodge
Stealth, Blindness, and Invisibility do not cause attacks to surprise you.
8 - Reliable Talent
If you roll less than 10 on a skill check, instead roll a 10.
item.guid: Classes/Rogue/Rogue.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Rogue - Bandit
item.description:
A professional thief, a blur of shadows around the battlefield taking everything their opponents have and stepping back before they realize what happened.
Your very shadow steps out to reach into people's pockets when they aren't looking.
1 - Pickpocket
Crits drop coins around the target. When collected, roll Crit Damage to see how many you get; if you collect them, it's worth quadruple. You can collect the coins as a free action, but other creatures must spend an action to collect or otherwise move the money. Before it's looted or moved, the coins are Blood Money.
This ability represents taking something away from your opponent with each hit. If you use it while sparring or against allies to "farm" money, they may need that money back to replace the golden tooth they lost, jewelry you pilfered, the kidney you stole etc.
DM discretion.
1 - Cunning Action: Steal
You can use Cunning Action to Steal. You can use Steal to produce Blood Money once per creature.
Your Cunning Actions have +10 reach.
1 - Coin Explosion (Recharge)
Action-Attack. Explode ALL of your Blood Money, dealing your Critical Damage for every pile exploded in their tiles and adjacent tiles. The damage stacks, including with overlap (Reflex halves). You are immune to this damage.
Even though each explosion is a separate instance of damage, creatures only roll their save once against all of them.
2 - Band of Thieves Companion Summoning
You can easily find and hire goons to call upon for aid. These are humanoids with half your HP (including when summoned), and +1 DEX and LUK. They are half your level. They have no other abilities or statistics of their own (no techniques, feats, class features, etc).
You may equip them as you please, and Summon them as a Cunning Action as per a Summoning Contract. They take their turn on your turn - the player controls them.
They can use Steal and Critical Hits to create Blood Money for you, using your statistics. They have their own limit for Steal.
4 - Grand Larceny
When you use the Steal action, you can Steal from everything in reach.
4 - Coin Collection
Gain +20% Wealth.
6 - Assaulter Recharge Teleportation
Action-Attack. Teleport to an enemy that is Surprised, up to 30ft, and attack.
8 - Advanced Dark Sight
Steal no longer ends Dark Sight.
Crits no longer end Dark Sight.
item.guid: Classes/Rogue/Rogue - Bandit.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Concealment
item.description:
Concealment is a Circumstance that is gained when a creature's position is being obscured from another's Senses.
Usually, this means an effect like fog or darkness is partially or totally hiding a creature from another, resulting in Partial Concealment or Total Concealment, but this may take other forms against creatures that have other senses.
Concealment is a condition that's relative to the senses of other creatures. If you have Dark Vision and your opponent doesn't in a situation with Darkness, you have concealment against them, but they don't have concealment to you.
Attacking from concealment, even Total Concealment, does not Surprise by default. You still need to use Stealth as normal.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Concealment.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Cover
item.description:
Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 4.
Standard Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and Area Effects that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure a large portion of your space, and that cannot be pierced by the attack.
Better forms of cover result in Improved Cover and Total Cover.
Examples include peeking around a pillar, over a trench, or behind a low wall.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Cover.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Improved Cover
item.description:
Improved Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 8.
Improved Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure almost all of your space, usually intentionally designed to allow attacks only in one direction, and that cannot be pierced by the attack.
Examples include arrow slits and murder holes., as well as ranged weapon attacks against Submerged targets.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Improved Cover.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Partial Concealment
item.description:
Partial Concealment is a Circumstance that grants +4 AC.
When you have Partial Concealment, a creature can still see you, but in a limited capacity. Either they can only see your shadow, they're trying to avert your gaze, or there are poor environmental conditions/magic at play.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Partial Concealment.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Total Concealment
item.description:
Total Concealment is a Circumstance that grants +10 AC.
When you have Total Concealment, a creature cannot see you at all. Either they are Blind, you are completely hidden in an environmental or magical effect, or you are Invisible.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Concealment.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Total Cover
item.description:
Total Cover is an environmental Circumstance that makes you Untargetable.
Total Cover is received against Ranged Attacks, AoEs, and Targeted Abilities that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that leave no way to reach you, and that cannot be pierced by the attack (in the case of Ranged Attacks and Area Effects.)
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Cover.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Abbreviations
item.description:
AC - Avoidability Capacity AKA Avoidability or Avoid
ACC - Accuracy
AoE - Area of Effect
CC - Debilitating Status AKA Crowd Control
DM - Dungeon Master
HP - Hit Points
LV - Level
NPC - Non-Player Character
PC - Player Character
CHA - Charisma
DEX - Dexterity
INT - Intelligence
LUK - Luck
STR - Strength
WIS - Wisdom
AoO - Attack of Opportunity
AS - Attack Speed
Crit - Critical Hit
DC - Difficulty Class AKA Target Number
D - Dismissible
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Abbreviations.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: AC
item.description:
Avoidability Capacity (AC) is the measure of how difficult it is to hit you. Targets must meet or exceed your AC with an Attack to Damage you or succeed at a Combat Maneuver.
By default, your starting AC is 10, and you add your LV, DEX, LUK, and Armor, and adjust it based on Circumstance.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: ACC
item.description:
Accuracy (ACC): What you add to your Attacks to beat a target's AC.
By default, you add your LV, DEX, and bonuses from your Class to your accuracy.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/ACC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: AoE
item.description:
Stands for "Area of Effect." It is used as shorthand to describe an attack that affects a wide area, such as an explosion, or a line of fire from a dragon's breath.
Area attacks have a point of origin. When the origin is a creature, such as with a breath weapon, determine Cover from one specific point in its occupied space. If the origin is a targeted point in space, such as with an explosion radiating outward, that point should be used to determine cover.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AoE.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: CC
item.description: A Debilitating Status (CC) is one that impedes your movement or prevents you from taking actions normally.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/CC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: DC
item.description: Difficulty Class (DC) is the target number that a Roll must reach to be considered a success.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: DM
item.description: Dungeon Master (DM): The person running the game. This person is the arbiter of the rules, tasked with creating the world, playing all NPCs, and ensuring a fun and fair experience for the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DM.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Initiative
item.description:
As a Turn-Based Game, Initiative decides who goes first.
Initiative is d10+Reflex. Some bonuses apply specifically to Initiative.
Whoever rolls higher goes first. Ties are broken first by the higher bonus, then PCs take priority.
In the event where there are two parties that don't immediately fight, initiative starts when someone takes an aggressive action, such as casting a spell or drawing an arrow. In these cases, where both parties are aware of each other, initiative gets rolled immediately before any actions happen, but the individual that took the aggressive action gains a +10 bonus to their Initiative. This means being the first to say "I attack!" usually means going first.
Certain types of underhanded tactics can affect who goes first, such as using Hands to draw a concealed weapon or Deception for a sucker punch.
Anyone that is not aware of combat is placed below anyone that was aware when initiative was rolled, regardless of their initiative result. This usually happens as a result of Stealth or an attack against sleeping opponents.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Initiative.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Lv
item.description: Level (LV): the level assigned to a creature or effect is used to represent their relative strength in the setting. Level is added to all Rolls (Attacks, Saving Throws, Skills, etc.)
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Lv.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: NPC
item.description:
Non-Player Character (NPC): Any character that is played by the DM.
These characters usually get placed after PCs to favor the players.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/NPC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: PC
item.description:
Player Character (PC): A character controlled by a player, and not the DM. Players are the main characters of a story, and thus gain port priority in some aspects.
Sometimes, a DM will play a special character alongside the players that is treated like a PC. This is normal, but the players can veto such a character's PC status if they feel it is inappropriate.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/PC.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Threaten
item.description: The area a creature threatens represents where they can make attacks. This usually only applies to melee attacks. This area also marks where it is typically not safe to perform certain actions, or risk getting hit with an AoO.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Threaten.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Ability Scores
item.description:
These are representations of a creature's innate or cultivated affinities. These represent the mind, body, and spirit. The ability scores are Strength, Dexterity, Luck, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.
Every Player Character gets 3 points to increase their ability scores as they wish, starting from 0 in each.
You can decrease a single ability score to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest in a given ability score is 2.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Ability Scores.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Carry Weight
item.description:
A creature's Carry Weight represents what it is capable of lifting and moving around with without much effort.
The default value is 100, but some factors may change this.
A creature can lift and drag twice as much as their carry weight, but is staggered while doing so.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Carry Weight.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: WIS
item.description:
Wisdom (WIS): Your faith, decision making, habits, diligence, and discipline.
You add WIS to your Will Save.
You gain 50% more XP per point of WIS.
You gain a Feat per Wisdom.
Negative WIS subtracts from your Will Save, Feats, and reduces your XP gain to 50%.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/WIS.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Fly
item.description:
Fly Speeds allow Movement in any direction. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly Speed - Flying targets get +4 AC against Ranged Attacks while flying.
A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight.
A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy +1 until they land, up to 6 stacks.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Fly.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Movement
item.description:
You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn.
Abilities that move you do not cost or consume any of your movement unless otherwise stated.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Movement.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Action System
item.description:
This game is played turn-based, with turn order determined at the start of the battle with an Initiative roll. The actions you can take on your turn are as follows.

Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn.
Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details.

Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn.
Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason.
Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your free Movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action.

When it's not your turn, you can take the following actions:

Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action — you cannot use both in the same round.
Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
Attack of Opportunity: A response triggered by certain actions of others. Limited to one per round. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them.
Movement: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Action System.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: AoO
item.description: Attack of Opportunity (AoO): An instant action basic attack triggered in response to certain actions of others. All creatures can do this once per round by default. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/AoO.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Free Action
item.description:
Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason.
See:
Delay
Swap Item
Monster Lore
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Free Action.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Instant Action
item.description: Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Instant Action.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Standard Action
item.description:
Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn.
Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details.
See:
Administer Potion
Aid
Attack Action
Carry
Charge
Dash
Disengage
Prepare
Total Defense
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Standard Action.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Swift Action
item.description:
Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn.

See:
Hide
Jump
Potion
Recharge Abilities
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Swift Action.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Attack Action
item.description:
When you take the Attack Action, you dedicate your turn to all-out offense. This allows you to make a number of attacks up to your highest Attack Speed, in any non-conflicting combination. Attack Speed is a product of which weapon you have on hand, but not all attacks must be with a weapon.
Action-Attack are a special type of "action," which by default have an Attack Speed of 1. Most combat spells, combat maneuvers, and special attacks are Action-Attacks. You can also activate these as a regular Standard Action.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Attack Action.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Total Defense
item.description: Get +4 to AC and Saves until the start of your next turn. Remove all Clumsy stacks. You can't make an AoO while using Total Defense.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Total Defense.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Recharge Abilities
item.description:
Regain all uses of your Recharge abilities.
When you use this action, you cannot use it again for one minute.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Recharge Abilities.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Alternative Win Conditions
item.description:
For when killing everything that moves isn't what you want, alternative win conditions seek to answer the question of "How do I end combat without reducing the enemy hp to 0?"
See:
Restraint
Surrender and Morale
Truce
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Alternative Win Conditions.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Restraint
item.description:
#Cuffs #Rope #Container
When creatures don't surrender, but you don’t want to risk killing them, restraints can be used to end the fight. Some situations can naturally be neutralized by dropping a cage in the right place, but such conveniences are rare. More often than not, restraining your foe is going to involves rope and cuffs.
#Cuffs
Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to put cuffs on them.
One grab is needed per appendage cuffed. You cannot cuff a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO.
This completely prevents the use of their arms outside of simple item interactions. Cuffs can also be placed on the legs to reduce a creatures speed to 15. Combat maneuvers made against a cuffed creature gain a +10 bonus.
Cuffs are difficult to escape, and even harder to break. They typically require outside assistance in order to be removed. Because cuffs are typically made from iron and steel, they can take a significant beating.
DC to break (Athletics) or lockpick (Hands) is dependent on the type of material and the lock. A typical forged cuff is DC 40 to break, or 20 to pick.
Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty.
#Rope
Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to tie them with rope.
One grab is needed per appendage tied. You cannot tie up a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO.
Rope is easier to destroy than cuffs, but it is also easier to make the restraint more intense. By grabbing one more time, you can prevent the creature from acting completely.
Rope tends to be a good way to bind singular creatures, since anybody with a sharp implement can handily free a bound creature.
Rope can be destroyed with an attack from any slashing weapon. Using Athletics or Acrobatics, you can pull the ropes apart, but the DC is determined by the athletics bonus of the creature who bound you (30+their athletics bonus). Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. This penalty can be ignored with a natural attack suitable for freeing yourself, or a slashing concealed weapon.
#Container
Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to forcefully shove them into an object within reach such as a bag, barrel, or box, so long as they can handily fit in the object.
Whether or not they can escape generally depends on the object and the tools the captured creature has on hand. Wooden crates don’t do to well when trying to hold barbarians or crafty characters with crowbars.
DC to break (Athletics) is dependent on the type of material. Some objects can be handily dealt with, not requiring a skill check. A knife makes quick work of a bag, and given enough space, hammers break boxes.
Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Restraint.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Surrender and Morale
item.description:
During combat there come times when you do not wish to fight, usually when one side is close to victory, but can also happen when creatures are clearly outnumbered or outmatched.
How well a surrender feels in a situation usually comes down to a gut feeling, affected by a lot of variables. In order to even consider a surrender to be viable, one or more of the following (or other applicable) conditions should be met…
Numbers advantage
Some other clear advantage, such as terrain, positioning, equipment or a powerful noteworthy ally
Heavily damaged or unconscious allies
Consequences for not surrendering (often death or further prosecution)
Hostages
Whether or not creatures are minions or named characters
A surrender requires clear communication, which may not always be possible given the hectic and spread out nature of battle. Some creatures, particularly mindless ones, will not surrender unless specific circumstances are met. Creatures of animal intelligence can be convinced to surrender if you can speak to animals or have wild empathy etc.
Surrender can mean forfeiting weapons, fleeing in fear, begging for mercy or something similar. If not all individuals accept the surrender, then the fight continues until they do.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Surrender and Morale.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Truce
item.description:
In situations where there are two opposing sides that are generally neutral towards each other or even allies with each other, you can call for a truce. This generally requires important information (we were sent by the merchants guild), certification from an important or recognizable organization (legal documentation) or a special item (an artifact or flag).
It could also be appropriate to call for a truce if you are delving into a dungeon and encounter another party, so long as you aren't after the same thing. You might not cooperate, but at least you won't be killing each other. If more information is revealed by talking throughout a battle (wait you're also hunting for the garbooni?), you can also reasonably call for a truce.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Truce.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Action-Attack
item.description: Action-Attacks are actions that can either be used as a Standard Action or as an attack with an AS of 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Action-Attack.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Combat Maneuver
item.description:
Combat Maneuvers are Action-Attack that target AC. AC should have separate notes for bonuses towards specific maneuvers. You add both STR and DEX to these attacks, rather than just DEX. When making a Combat Maneuver, you must decide which specific form it takes, such as a Fell, Dirty Trick, or Shove. A successful Combat Maneuver will inflict a condition based on the form you chose.
See:
Dirty Trick
Disarm
Drag
Feint
Fell
Grab
Shove
Steal
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Combat Maneuver.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Disarm
item.description: Knock a held item out of a creature’s hand, landing at their feet. It takes 30 ft of Movement or a Standard Action to pick up an item off the ground, which Provokes.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Disarm.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Feint
item.description:
Feint is the use of Deception vs the target's Insight.
Feint is NOT considered an Attack, but you can still use your ACC in place of Deception. It is still classified as a Combat Maneuver, and can benefit from any bonuses or defenses relevant to them.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Feint.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Fell
item.description: Inflict Knocked Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Fell.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Steal
item.description:
You take an item that is not in the target's hands, but is otherwise accessible on their person.
Steal can use Hands in place of ACC.
Worn Equipment is assumed to be ineligible targets unless it is an Accessory.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Steal.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Line of Effect
item.description: A straight line between two places with no Total Cover or impassable obstacles for a given effect grants Line of Effect. This is different from sight, as you may be able to see someone and not Target them (such as through a window).
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Line of Effect.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Switching Weapons
item.description:
At the start of your turn, you can decide what's in your hands from your inventory. You can draw and put away any weapons without penalty. This is a Free Action as long as it's done at the start of your turn. If you decide to change what you're wielding at another point in your turn, it becomes a Swift Action - and you can't do both.
Handedness is an important concept here. When you use your hand for something other than a free action, you usually cannot use it for something else on the same turn. The main exception to this is Two-Handed items, which allow you to let go with one hand to perform an action. Any other exceptions should be handled with discretion.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Switching Weapons.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Targeted
item.description: A Targeted ability refers to one where you must select targets to apply the effect, which is not an Attack Roll. Some abilities are particular about what they work on, and will fail if used outside of their scope. You must have Line of Effect and be able to see your target to target them. If you cannot see them, you must target their space with the intention of targeting them.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Targeted.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Ashen One
item.description:
In dark souls, certain types of creatures, namely the player character, hold a special place in the world's lore. When you die you don't reload the game, you canonically respawn at the location you last rested, leaving behind all your money where you died.
You could choose to adopt a similar system where certain types of conditions need to be met for these unique creatures to die for real. Having the characters lose all their money might not be the best approach for a TTRPG: players like their money. But, in souls games you can go back to the place you died and collect the money again, so maybe.
This kind of natural respawn mechanic is a good fit for campaigns where you expect your players to encounter dangerous creatures on the regular and your players don't get too discouraged from losing. Meat grinder without the consequences of losing your character for good.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Ashen One.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Cloning Device
item.description:
You start off your adventures waking up in some alchemist's lab, surrounded in copies of yourself. Whenever you die, there is a fresh body waiting for you back at the lab that your soul gets sucked into.
This plays more into having a secret base type thing, and it feels a little less metagame-y than "chosen by god." it also has an interesting mystery component to it. Why were you guys chosen as clones? Whose lab is this? How's that for storytelling with resurrection?
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Cloning Device.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Death and Resurrection
item.description:
The purpose of resurrection in TTRPGs is primarily for the benefit of the players. If a DM makes frequent use of the resurrection spells for entities that the players went to great lengths to kill, it heavily undermines their effort and feels terrible, even if plausible.
The powers that be should instead be very particular about the who gets a second chance. If the players are the main character of the story, then the game's resurrection mechanics should treat them as such. As a replacement for most resurrection effects, use these rules instead. Or don't use resurrection at all. It's your game. Whatever.
IMPORTANT NOTE: Please make sure your players are on board with whatever you decide. Nobody likes surprise mechanics.
See:
Ashen One
Cloning Device
Limited Resurrection
Tombstone
Withers
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Death and Resurrection.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Limited Resurrection
item.description:
Pose a caveat to resurrection magic that imposes a severely limiting factor, such as only being able to revive a creature shortly after it died with some kind of resource attached to it. Maybe even make it a limited resource by tying it to physical items, like scrolls with this effect attached to it.
EFFECT

DESCRIPTION You breathe new life into a recently deceased creature. If the creature has died within the last minute, they are brought back to life at 1 hp and drained 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Limited Resurrection.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Tombstone
item.description:
In the event of your characters untimely demise, worry not, for the gods smile upon you. When killed, your body becomes a tombstone with your name and face on it. It weighs as much as you did, including all of your equipment. This tombstone can be carried back somewhere to perform a ritual and bring the character back to life.
This can be a place of significance to this god, something generic like a church or something with more story relevance. It can be wherever home base is, or you can require the players to reach certain points in the campaign in order to get their characters resurrected (Ex: Your friend died by the lich's hand, and now, to get them back, you have to destroy his phylactery. Make a temp character!).
The basic idea is there: satisfy this entity's conditions and life will be restored.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Tombstone.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Withers
item.description:
In Baldur's Gate 3, there is an NPC that shows up in your camp that has a vested interest in your success. He has powers that aren't like normal characters, chief among them the ability to resurrect fallen allies. You could easily introduce a similar character into your campaign, maybe even the introduction to the campaign is this NPC resurrecting the players.
This particular method has the benefit of being less nebulous than divine forces. It gives someone the players can interact with and someone that can give them direction. Whatever the reason they have for resurrecting your players, it's because they need their help.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Withers.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Defeat
item.description:
When a creature falls to 0 HP, they gain the Defeated condition. They cannot do anything more than a mild whisper while at or below 0 HP. If they are healed to positive hit points, they do not lose the Defeated condition, but they may Crawl at a rate of 10 feet per turn, or move at full speed when assisted by another creature.
This mostly only applies to important characters. A character is important when the players and DM agree as such (often the player characters themselves, an NPC relevant to the story, or a major villain). When an important character defeats an unimportant character, it is assumed they are killed outright unless otherwise stated by the characters attacking.
If a creature reaches an amount of negative HP equal to its maximum HP, it dies outright.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Defeat.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Healing
item.description: Healing is an effect that restores current HP up to your maximum HP, grants Temp HP, or removes debilitating status conditions.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Healing.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Long Rest
item.description:
Taking a Long Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 8 hours, during which you sleep to benefit from Natural Healing.
Proper rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Long Rest.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Natural Healing
item.description:
Naturally Healing requires eating Food. Food restores varying amounts of HP based on the food eaten. You must take a Short Rest to eat food. The amount recovered is based on the food.
With a Long Rest, a character restores all of their HP and all of their Limited abilities. You can only Long Rest once each day. You must have eaten at least once since the last time you Long Rested, or else you will not recover HP.
A proper Long Rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Natural Healing.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Recovering from Defeat
item.description:
After being Defeated for an hour after the last time it took damage, a creature may attempt to shake off the condition with a STR Roll. On a 10 or higher, they lose the Defeated condition, but as long as their HP remains negative, they are Staggered. On a fail, they lose 5 HP.
After successfully recovering, the creature is Drained by d4-LUK. This drain cannot kill the creature.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Recovering from Defeat.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Rest
item.description: Take a Short Rest or Long Rest.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Rest.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Short Rest
item.description: Taking a Short Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 15 minutes, where you can eat and stretch and wipe your brow to benefit from Natural Healing.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Short Rest.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Temp HP
item.description:
Temporary Hitpoints (Temp HP) are gained separately from your HP. They are lost before your HP, and multiple sources do not stack - only the highest applies.
Unless otherwise stated, Temp HP only lasts 1 minute.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Temp HP.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Fall Damage
item.description:
Fall damage increases by 3 Crush for every 10 feet you fall, capped at 60 damage. Every 50 feet you are also Drained 1, capped at 4.
When determining fall distance, subtract your Jump.
If you fall further than your AC (Trip), you are Knocked Down.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Fall Damage.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Light Level
item.description:
Light comes in 3 forms.
Bright Light A sunny day or a torch lit room. Bright light let's creatures see things clearly. Most creatures can see in bright light without any penalty.
Dim Light Moonlight or at the edge of your torch light. Many humanoids cannot see well in dim light. Features in dim light appear only as a silhouette with dull, if any, color. Without special senses, creatures have Partial Concealment in dim light.
Darkness The depths of a cave or deep underwater. Few creatures can see clearly in a complete darkness. Some, such as humans, can't see at all. Those that can (such as with night vision or Darkvision) still only see in grayscale. Without special senses, creatures have Total Concealment in darkness.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Light Level.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Rounding Numbers
item.description: Always round decimals down, minimum 1.
item.guid: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Rounding Numbers.md
item.dc:creator: Malon Elenia

item.title: Size and Reach
item.description:
This game is meant to be played on a grid of hexes or squares. Personally, I prefer hexes. Creatures must be represented in such a space. That's why creatures are broken up into size categories.

Creatures threaten all spaces they occupy by default.
You can enter the space of a creature that is a size category larger or smaller than you. If you leave a space occupied by a creature, it provokes an AoO as though you were leaving a threatened area.
